9c2e267d-de1f-401b-b430-fa1d53d5980e	ONCE YOU MAKE UP your mind about an investment, the rest is easy, right
05c70e04-f035-4ed9-9d64-fea3fe20a77f	You just call your broker and say "buy" or "sell
f9c36062-16fa-439f-bc27-1b207304cb0a	Dream on
2c2c3444-86a2-4fad-a10f-4ca82ea490eb	There are all sorts of ways to give buy and sell instructions to a broker -- and just as many ways to get burned if you don't know what you're doing
9028aa20-5fe4-42d8-8c58-a20186862a6f	With a market order, an investor tells a broker to buy or sell "at the market
00fb1f1f-86d6-4a5f-bab4-186e60f296bc	It's like saying, "get me in now" or "get me out now
d76d0351-7451-46ce-a1f9-db3ad05995ca	Suppose an investor wants to sell a stock, but not for less than $55
c7e80657-421a-4d0c-ba1e-9c94a5599851	A limit order to sell could be entered at that price
ee4e4f45-f6e2-46cb-b603-4bd3419108ab	Stop orders tell a floor broker to buy or sell an investment once the price reaches a certain level
bf4469b7-76f8-435b-ba05-4c20df246e2d	Once the price reaches that level, a stop order turns into a market order, and the order is filled at whatever price the broker can get
60339a1d-c97f-41c4-9f95-43435678eebe	Unlike stop orders stop-limit orders demand that the trades be made only at the specified price
f011cfd0-1e0a-425a-9a33-92605a91b2b2	If it can't be made at that price, it doesn't get filled
201f7709-8c8f-47b2-a5c5-316ba55e0eb0	he uses fill-or-kill orders almost exclusively when trading options
b4f44df8-33f6-47dc-b4cf-c0bf43ec27d3	I like to use them to feel out the market
febf9001-6c56-4155-b2ee-51177f4cc993	This is really two orders in one, generally for the same security or commodity, instructing floor brokers to fill whichever order they can first and then cancel the other order
06343535-480c-438e-b983-9de19eb31399	In a fast-moving market, it prevents an investor from getting stuck with having made two trades on the same security
0c040ae5-3966-400c-b199-46ca891e4851	On Oct. 19, 1987, some investors learned the consequences of entering "good-til-canceled limit orders" and then forgetting about them

b9c25fbb-1e11-4ac4-bd0b-d65a4daa0f16	Litigation consulting is highly manipulative
b8ed04d6-2823-4de3-9759-c8b8f4adaa13	The notion they try to sell is that juries don't make decisions rationally
fa2aaf55-3be8-4842-8e1c-701c48702336	that consultants can be very effective
11ec1a75-2dbb-49e6-9029-d76222cea97b	It's gotten to the point where if the case is large enough, it's almost malpractice not to use them
701b204d-c772-4490-8e61-ce32ffe69361	Sophisticated trial consulting grew, ironically, from the radical political movements of the 1960s and 1970s before finding its more lucrative calling in big commercial cases
058b03a1-55ed-4481-8afe-68b2c3570f15	The Harrisburg 7 trial in 1972, in which Daniel Berrigan and others were charged with plotting anti-war-related violence, was a landmark
2d2a67a6-23df-417f-9d3a-21343d9a42ee	In that case, a group of left-leaning sociologists interviewed 252 registered voters around Harrisburg
7384e482-4d94-498c-913a-3e5c9182e119	The researchers discovered that Episcopalians, Presbyterians, Methodists and fundamantalist Protestants were nearly always against the defendants
b14e4ce8-c474-44aa-ae0b-4b3d6c37831e	Ultimately, that carefully picked jury deadlocked with a 10-2 vote to acquit, and the prosecution decided not to retry the case

c9206560-0734-4bf8-93d8-1d9366c066ef	So here's a rundown of the most common types of market orders permitted by the stock and commodity exchanges
725541ed-3da0-4add-bfaf-c01b9b3c44ca	Two things to keep in mind
7820569e-ba9f-4a45-aabe-fe1ab38a8037	Two things to keep in mind
be1cb619-e282-4f15-b448-92ee11ef26e3	Not all exchanges accept every type of order
2d471049-6d40-46b8-9c55-fc416df52ba6	For example, if wheat is being offered at $4.065 and bid at $4.060, a market order to buy would be filled at the higher price and a market order to sell at the lower price
4f3e8a84-c57f-43f9-b8d6-39ff404fe6d2	that some floor brokers at the two largest Chicago commodity exchanges used market orders to fill customers' orders at unfavorable prices by arranging trades with fellow brokers
09391e77-bf9a-4c8f-a392-fa0e583f2a19	Investors do this by specifying a minimum price at which the investment may be sold or the maximum price that may be paid for it
fd6e4f28-c412-4a20-b19c-43145f1f93d4	Suppose an investor wants to sell a stock, but not for less than $55
e5ba0bf4-50b0-454f-bc75-59746472c006	Once the price reaches that level, a stop order turns into a market order, and the order is filled at whatever price the broker can get
b2e72eca-1725-4805-a3d7-03db16cf391d	Stop orders are sometimes called "stop-loss" orders because they are frequently used to protect profits or limit losses
4f809c76-e623-41fe-81fb-1fd82339e6d9	While stop orders sound similar to limit orders, there is a difference
aadcd44e-85c7-4ffc-a0d8-4d78aea276e9	Sell stops must be entered at a price below the current market price and buy stops above.
d03eb74a-f2b3-4bb2-b92b-681a025085df	The crash in October 1987 and last Friday's sell-off painfully taught some investors exactly what stop orders will and won't do
2567f795-02ed-491f-8344-7b204e51fe5e	An investor who may have placed a stop-loss order at $90 under a stock that was trading at $100 a share on the Friday before the crash was stunned to discover that the order was filled at $75 when the stock opened at that price on Monday
caecd230-c8c4-42d3-a745-72a1c85f1b9a	The fill-or-kill order is one of several associated with the timing of trades
15801b4e-4be9-42df-b8b4-8dfbb33235d3	It instructs a broker to buy or sell an investment at the specified price or better
3640c726-97dc-45d0-a0c6-1939370c85fc	I like to use them to feel out the market
d970540a-35bd-4dd7-aadd-41f1c0bf3791	If they don't fill it immediately, then I can start over at a new price or try again with the same price
8640232d-23e1-42c5-a226-06e5d829a1a4	This is another timing order
7dba2d30-b6a7-4661-b3fd-4197e6d35aba	It is a market order that allows floor brokers to take more time to buy or sell an investment, if they think they can get a better price by waiting
26339997-fba7-4728-a0fe-d84f7c5db467	This type of order couples many of the orders described above with instructions that the order must be carried out at or by a certain time
c2ab3b23-5f83-49c5-91ae-d7ccdda64db5	On the close" can be added to many types of orders
329f2a40-8a04-4b4c-aea9-b601155a4a7b	Stop-close-only orders" are stop orders that only become active during the closing minutes of trading
2b885aa1-c0b6-4a8d-ac5c-83afa2306328	Day orders" expire at the end of the day on which they are entered, "good-till-canceled orders" have no expiration date

b06e097c-ac8b-4131-afd1-d4558311428c	So do just about all the losses that could be attributed to the sheer incompetence of unqualified planners

b28c333e-4b27-444c-b782-f769f809d24c	Over the past decade or two the insurance industry has spawned an incredible number of products, variations on products, and variations on the variations
57996d8b-7a27-4d96-bf7b-bb211144c58c	Besides term life and whole life (the old standbys), we now have universal life, universal variable life, flexible adjustable universal life, policies with persistency bonuses, policies festooned with exotic riders, living benefit policies, and on and on
315316f1-ad8f-4064-ad6a-218d8b0ebf2e	First, generalize
af64357c-51fa-4374-b288-37237f9321cf	Shorn of all their riders, special provisions, and other bells and whistles, insurance policies can still be grouped under two broad categories: so-called pure insurance, which amasses no cash value in the policy and pays off only upon death, and permanent insurance, which provides not only a death benefit but also a cash value in the policy that can be used in various ways while the insured is still alive
29a15a95-a7be-4086-bf8c-fab28afec043	If all you want is death-benefit coverage, pure insurance -- a term policy -- gives you maximum bang for your buck, within limits
4077ecf7-fcf7-4b28-89fa-eaa6b9da7d0b	It's much cheaper than permanent insurance bought at the same age
1a2a588f-61ba-41be-a002-be7c186f4bec	But "term" means just that
d399454e-18c5-4b2b-ba66-76eebbd4e424	the policy is written for a specific time period only and must be renewed when it expires
7947d161-180a-47c9-9719-4b404aac0418	if you flunk you may not be able to buy it
6515bdb7-72bc-411d-9d1c-53dd934d4f5f	Even if you're healthy and can renew, your premium will go up sharply because you're that much older

aef70179-8336-4d4b-91b1-bbdbf13a49f1	Which goes to show that the First Law applies in insurance as in anything else
5aad7c2d-be0d-4ffc-ab6f-5a13ebc81d52	There is no free lunch, there is only marketing

af738613-850d-4caf-99e8-e849a49888a6	You pay a set premium for a set amount of coverage, the company invests that premium in a portfolio of its choosing, and your cash value and dividends grow over the years
06ce7fee-fc57-45f0-8ef2-c171f8eb8ad1	Hugely popular, it is far more flexible than straight whole life

bf6e96ca-0050-4408-b7f4-d5bbd8d8f874	In only one presidential election year prior to 1948 did more than 20% of the nation's congressional districts choose a different party's candidate for the White House than for the House of Representatives.
fc1a5e29-531e-4650-84b7-231b38479095	As we know, voters tend to favor Republicans more in races for president than in those for Congress
777686d4-6fbb-4bc3-8f4b-c36ebb9ec012	In every presidential election over the past half century, except for the Goldwater presidential candidacy, the GOP has captured a greater percentage of the major-party popular vote for president than it has of congressional seats or the popular vote for Congress
20b936d6-bca7-4861-b375-67838e56500f	If these assumptions hold, voters in races for Congress face what in economic theory is called a prisoner's dilemma and have an incentive, at the margin, to lean Democratic
1c4f7b93-2591-4b57-9582-88fe8b4db58c	If they put a Republican into office, not only will they acquire less in terms of local benefits but their selected legislator will be relatively powerless to prevent other legislators from "bringing home the bacon" to their respective constituencies
b7b469a9-58fb-48bd-96e4-1015f9381016	Second, it explains why voters hold Congress in disdain but generally love their own congressional representatives
1b2c1ab1-80ac-4e74-9ca5-9c8ed36af522	Any individual legislator's constituents appreciate the specific benefits that the legislator wins for them but not the overall cost associated with every other legislator doing likewise for his own constituency
e6fd9f6c-1c1c-4db5-b18f-cb8aea36573a	The one exception to this recent trend was the defeat of 13 of the 52 freshman Republicans brought into office in 1980 by the Reagan revolution and running for re-election in 1982
41b0faee-6ce8-43d6-b1b3-9a9d4f2a2fd3	Because these freshmen placed far more emphasis on their partisan role -- spreading the Reagan revolution -- in national policy making, they were more vulnerable to defeat
cbc85b0e-a15c-4411-86b7-d23da745bd78	Fourth, the theory indicates why the Republican Party may have a difficult time attracting viable candidates for congressional office
42d03ac2-e044-4471-9b45-d1c0134d4666	Potential candidates may be discouraged from running less by the congressional salary than by the prospect of defeat at the hands of a Democratic opponent
a755450d-7853-473d-89af-f14832f67000	Fifth, the theory may provide at least a partial reason for why ticket splitting has been particularly pronounced in the South
f6a76313-3137-4cfd-a8c3-0fe8ce81e865	To the extent that Democratic legislators from the South have held a disproportionate share of power in Congress since 1932 and have been able to translate such clout into relatively more local benefits for their respective constituencies, voters in the South have had an especially strong incentive to keep such Democrats in office
aeed3b81-ddef-4890-9173-d283f3adb492	Finally, the theory suggests why Republicans generally have fared better in Senate races than in campaigns for the House
eda27d70-1b83-4aed-b10e-3ba60f109041	Since local benefit-seeking matters more and national policy making matters less in the lower chamber of Congress, this is precisely the pattern one would expect if Republicans are less willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their Democratic counterparts
1e17b204-02d6-47ae-b3af-6cecef469489	This is indeed what the data indicate, particularly in the case of the House

b92698d6-b16e-4737-90da-0f638386f453	that the task facing Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan is so difficult that it resembles "juggling a double-bladed ax and a buzz saw
d0b9990b-892b-4714-b567-128928efcdca	And, in a sense, that's the kind of task individuals face in deciding what to do about stocks
1d7f0f98-baf3-4862-a28e-d5f2539e44de	It comes down to a question of whether to try to "time" the market
e680054d-80ce-47c4-9bd3-a475438e7ec1	For people who can ride out market waves through good times and bad, stocks have been rewarding long-term investments
e8c474d0-f390-4750-b1a5-5f27f2ad9fa9	that buy-and-hold investors historically have earned an annual return from stocks of 9% to 10%
ddf6691e-e7cb-4d70-84d7-75fcfc1d8fd5	Trying to time the economy is a mistake," says David Katz, chief investment officer of Value Matrix Management Inc. in New York
2513e2f5-af69-4b7f-9a76-72f9de57e435	that some economists have been predicting a recession for at least two years
385c0e45-7322-4f0a-86ee-c49df317b771	that people who jump in and out of the stock market need to be right about 70% of the time to beat a buy-and-hold strategy
477d4a7f-b53e-4ba0-832a-b8bcf43789db	Frequent trading runs up high commission costs
595d5d30-737e-4b3a-83a3-534be634623c	After all, in all five recessions since 1960, stocks declined
eff153a5-8f20-4e5f-8c0b-fbf27c82fd60	According to Ned Davis, president of Ned Davis Research Inc. in Nokomis, Fla., the average drop in the Dow Jones Industrial Average was about 21%, and the decrease began an average of six months before a recession officially started

b39455ff-33d3-4c0a-b4b5-9a0ed5fc0e7f	Institutional investors have poured $210 billion into stock and bond indexing as a cheap and easy form of investment management that promises to post average market returns
65ad30df-dbfd-4472-9397-931c6f2d28fe	These big investors have flocked to indexing because relatively few "active" stock pickers have been able to consistently match the returns of the S&P 500 or other bellwethers, much less beat it
e702ec5d-ae4e-490b-930c-f60932bffef0	But today, indexing is moving from a passive investment strategy to an increasingly active one
03d8c7b5-857c-4a05-8bfd-231229b70c2a	Because index-fund managers are no longer satisfied with merely being average, they have developed "enhanced" indexing strategies that are intended to outperform the market as much as three percentage points
055747e7-bc79-4c9f-9656-643736fad36b	Indexed portfolios can be built around thousands of stocks, or just a few dozen, rather than being restricted to the S&P 500 companies
fc7e7572-90aa-44e0-b80a-c5f1147a3913	They can ignore the S&P 500 stocks altogether and focus on particular types of stocks, such as smaller companies, those paying high dividends or companies in a particular industry, state or country
767a4e8f-ece9-472a-b80f-920f277e45ab	A further problem is razor-thin profits
048a921f-0ba5-49b4-ac39-0493910830a8	Plain-vanilla funds have become so commonplace that fees they can charge have plunged to almost nothing, and in some cases are just that
08fd3da2-d83f-4b15-9777-17f2a1c3aa67	Plain-vanilla funds have become so commonplace that fees they can charge have plunged to almost nothing, and in some cases are just that
39571f0a-37b7-41b7-b7d2-aa503e69ec39	To land customers for their well-paying stock custodial business, big banks sometimes will throw in basic indexing services for free
c4ff8a2e-9298-4571-9d09-1f4a8b027be7	To land customers for their well-paying stock custodial business, big banks sometimes will throw in basic indexing services for free
c21547e2-2ae6-4c02-a8f8-4ab4f11d7b7d	It's like getting a free toaster when you open an account
e6ff2bbd-2e96-4494-9fb1-3042a3e4f2da	Strategies vary for Westridge Capital, which has $300 million under management
88580add-5c78-4879-8f66-5cdd6834ee13	The firm sometimes buys S&P 500 futures when they are selling at a discount to the actual stocks, and will switch back and forth between stocks and stock-index futures to take advantages of any momentary price discrepencies
d386cf5a-2812-4636-bbb9-b56bea1d66d5	By their nature, our trades are very short-term and are going to create high turnover
0a91ce60-ae41-43e2-9e5d-dceea27c4c62	The more turnover, the better for our clients
39aa1879-f3a7-4ddc-808b-03f609170bb3	Big indexer Bankers Trust Co. also uses futures in a strategy that on average has added one percentage point to its enhanced fund's returns
c2036bd5-7dec-4f19-8a82-6f5e340242ff	it's a good idea to jump between the S&P 500 stocks and futures
6e840195-f115-4df1-9204-80e1901384e1	There are many other strategies to bolster the returns of index funds
2c76102d-e0be-461a-8b16-16499e0ce687	They include:
3f43683b-ff0f-4add-b2be-368a176cbe30	LIMITED RISK FUNDS
36b1688f-500a-4186-8512-3e1be818397f	These guarantee protection against stock market declines while still passing along most gains
0f661680-55e6-4173-9eb2-214f465ce55f	These guarantee protection against stock market declines while still passing along most gains
eb8d6d92-0090-40b2-b7cf-000acc369976	Here a fund may promise to pay back, say, $95 of every $100 invested for a year, even if the market goes much lower
b3dda7e7-7e79-4767-b75a-b83b2c486399	This is an index fund with a bet

23aea08d-d998-46b7-a38e-97d5db277399	The exclusion would rise five percentage points for each year the asset was held until it reached a maximum of 35%

85b7cc82-76b8-4bc8-a051-9d33eefdf935	Only 23% of trash-bag users in the Journal survey usually buy the same brand, and just 29% of battery buyers stick to one brand

dd945906-97e0-4e0f-add1-588b1fa8c37d	There are two versions of "Measure for Measure" on stage at the Alley Theater here
d00ce260-3401-40b7-b80d-f778b124bedf	One is a strong, vigorous portrayal of Shakespeare's play; the other is director Gregory Boyd's overlay of present-day punk rock decadence on old Vienna
4b4c90a0-878e-4092-b1d2-adc08c2a72d6	Measure for Measure" is one of Shakespeare's "problem" plays, so named because it does not fit neatly into a category such as tragedy, comedy or history
f4b3638b-c51b-480a-b3cb-027d2f000124	Its ambiguity and uneasy mixture of the serious and the comic is no doubt one reason why it is very much in vogue with directors just now
f0b52eec-4d57-428f-8fce-9ea19da9ab3b	featuring a rectangular platform of white-washed boards that extends into the audience
49dc8da3-b6cd-401d-afab-febb747b02f8	When the action requires, a prison cell, consisting of an enlarged wire cage, rolls forward on iron wheels on the platform
fc022daa-bcaa-4c4f-9501-77c30ef2d831	In the play's major scenes Mr. Boyd demonstrates that he has a firm grasp of the Shakespearean dynamic
40355287-a38d-4267-b2d0-65776e5dfbb1	When Isabella (Ellen Lauren) confronts her brother Claudio (Matt Loney) in his cell, explaining the price she has been asked to secure his freedom; when Isabella and the disguised Duke (Philip Kerr) conspire to trick Angelo; and when Mariana (Annalee Jefferies), a woman wronged by Angelo, confronts him with his past misdeeds, the performers bring the dramatic high points to life with intense energy and intelligence
4518aa55-7877-4331-a5cb-a9ff211b3232	In his "Measure," Mr. Boyd has "modernized" the pimps and prostitutes of Vienna whom Angelo is supposed to bring under control by converting them into transvestites, punk rockers and heavy metal types, with a strong emphasis on leather, chains and porno-inspired costumes

40448854-a876-4998-8b48-970fc44f068f	Called a "married put," the technique is carried out by purchasing a stock and simultaneously buying a put option on that stock
bef2b9c7-0072-4985-919e-b86b17110ec1	It's like "fire insurance
cfebdc0b-db1d-44d9-8371-551ccd378ff6	Because a put option gives its owner the right, but not the obligation, to sell a fixed number of shares of the stock at a stated price on or before the option's expiration date, the investor is protected against a sudden drop in the stock's price
438e7ecb-c4ab-4633-a4af-e2afb352a0c5	If the price of the stock declines, the put will increase in value

1bbea11c-565f-4f01-8fe2-6165ca916df9	He theorized that in the eye cancer, an infant inherited a damaged copy of a gene from one parent and a normal copy from the other

8c75ffcd-78fc-48bc-a858-412b624fa144	The probe, which is painless, non-invasive and apparently harmless, employs strong magnetic fields to induce small whirlwinds of electricity within the brain
b95c9fd6-f8c1-433e-81cc-6438780f4a57	If positioned over the brain's motor-control area, the hand-held electromagnets generate nerve impulses that zip down motor nerves and activate muscles, making, say, a finger twitch

62251852-02c1-421e-8616-034cf4c0885e	These critics are backed by several academic studies showing that the adoption of poison pills reduces shareholder values not merely in the short run, but also over longer periods
82a86dd5-f525-4243-b09c-fd5e9934e622	Institutional investors that must evaluate poison pills on a regular basis are interested less in this general debate than in the answers to specific questions about the corporation issuing the pill

5e5cc3d0-42c4-441b-8d95-52598fe79818	Does this corporation have a high-quality management team with a good track record?
e6e7da38-dcb1-4b82-847d-fbca8a8476de	Will the adoption of this particular form of a poison pill significantly improve the chances for management to carry out this strategy
ce91c4e1-d67e-483f-b93b-72c963a24ed7	Although the current management team may be outstanding, who will be the CEO in 10 years
9e413f09-d794-4770-88bd-297f74af5558	Although the five-year strategy may be excellent, what will be the strategy in 25 years
f84ec4de-556b-4f7c-8fb5-a2dde63d9d8f	The solution to this problem is a time-limited poison pill
4963746c-1e68-448f-b5d9-c2787f37da3d	The limit could range from three years to seven years, depending on the composition of the management team and the nature of its strategic plan
727add08-8235-458a-8804-b8182be1fa84	One rare example of a time-limited poison pill is the shareholder rights plan adopted by Pennzoil last year after it received a huge litigation settlement from Texaco
eea1d3e8-6b54-479f-b0aa-e45875e80ba0	Pennzoil's poison pill covers five years in order to give current management enough time to put these proceeds to work in a prudent manner
